courses.description: Agritourism has a direct economic impact on farms and surrounding communities. This course will delve into the tourism industry, strategies to develop and maintain farms and their heritage as tourism products, as well as explore strategies to document and promote the economic and cultural significance of agritourism. Open to both majors and non-majors.
courses.name: Agritourism Dvlp/Promotion

courses.description: In order to understand the connection between agricultural traditions and heritage based tourism, one must understand the importance of resource strategies critical to the preservation and conservation of unique environmental and historical settings. This course will review the historical image of agriculturists and their connection to the land and how this connection ties to heritage based tourism. The course will delve into a variety of topics and methods to increase the importance of this new role awareness.
courses.name: Ag & Heritage-Based Tourism

courses.description: Direct marketing shortens the marketing route and allows businesses to communicate with and deliver products directly to the consumer. This course will cover key elements of direct marketing in an agrulture and human ecology context, including retailing, merchandizing, social media marketing and serbices makreting. Open to both majors and non-majors.
courses.name: Direct Mkt for AGR/HEC

courses.description: Prerequisite: ATOU2100 or consent of instructor. Sustainable tourism is a strategy for economic and community development in rural areas around the world. This course will trace the inception of these concepts from the United Nationals World Tourism Organization and follow their application in various locations, both internationally and within the US. Focus will be given to various types of niche tourism to achieve economic and community development goals.
courses.name: Sustnble Trsm/Econ & Comm Dvlp

courses.description: Introduction to concepts of biology and their relationships to current and future social problems. Non-biology majors only. Credit will not be given for both BIOL 1010 and BIOL 1113 (formerly BIOL 1105).
courses.name: Introduction to Biology

courses.description: Note: BIOL 1010 is not a prerequisite. Survey of plant and animal diversity, introductory ecology, and man's impact on the environment. Non-biology majors only.
courses.name: Diversity of Life

courses.description: Basic concepts of biology including botany, zoology, and environmental applications. This course will not count as a part of a biology sequence.
courses.name: Concepts of Biology

courses.description: A basic foundation in biological principles common to all organisms with an emphasis on molecules, cells and organelles, respiration, photosynthesis, metabolism and enzymatic function, genetics and inheritance, cellular reproduction, evolution, and speciation. Credit will not be given for both BIOL 1113 and BIOL 1010.
courses.name: General Biology I

courses.description: Introduction to the Principles of Zoology. Prerequisite: None, but BIOL1105 is highly recommended.
courses.name: General Zoology

courses.description: Introduction to principles of botany.
courses.name: General Botany

courses.description: Introduction to the principles of zoology and the diversity of life.
courses.name: General Biology II

courses.description: An introduction to biological terminology, including zoological, botanical, ecological, and medical terminology, with an emphasis on developing proficiency with the use of word roots and derivations.
courses.name: Biological Terminology

courses.description: Structure and function of the human body for nursing and other majors requiring a detailed examination of the topic. First course in a two course sequence. (See BIOL 2020).
courses.name: Human Anatomy & Physiology I

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 2010. Continuation of BIOL 2010.
courses.name: Human Anatomy & Physiology II

courses.description: This course addresses the life cycles, morphology, and phylogeny of major clades of organisms, with an emphasis on fungi, protists, and plants.
courses.name: General Botany

courses.description: An introductory course in human anatomy and physiology intended for students of health and physical education, human ecology, psychology, and other majors requiring a basic survey of the topics.
courses.name: Intro Anatomy & Physiology

courses.name: Topics

courses.description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor and departmental chairperson. Focused study equivalent to one, two, three, or four hours on a special topic in the life sciences or wildlife/fisheries sciences under faculty supervision and approval of the department chairperson. Course may be repeated until a maximum of 12 hours of combined credit in BIOL (WFS) 299- Topics or BIOL (WFS) 499- (599-) Advanced Topics courses are earned.
courses.name: Topics

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 1113 and BIOL 1123. Anatomy and phylogeny of vertebrates and comparative study of systems of representative types.
courses.name: Comparative Vertebrate Anatomy

courses.description: The relationship between plants and animals and their environment. This course can not be taken as part of the university science requirement and credit will not be given for both BIOL 3120 and BIOL/WFS 3130.
courses.name: General Ecology

courses.description: The relationship between plants and animals and their environment. The laboratory provides examples of concepts discussed in lecture and analytical procedures used in interpreting data. (Same as WFS 3130.)
courses.name: General Ecology

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 1123. An introduction to structure and function of cells.
courses.name: Cellular Biology

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 1123. Introduction to basic concepts of microbiology (non-medical). Intended for students not in health-science programs. Credit will not be given for both BIOL 3200 and BIOL 3230.
courses.name: General Microbiology

courses.description: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing. Introduction to microbiology. Intended for students majoring in nursing or other preprofessional programs. Credit will not be given for both BIOL 3200 and BIOL 3230.
courses.name: Health Science Microbiology

courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 2310 and Junior Standing. Survey of regional flora (herbs, shrubs, & trees) focusing on gymnosperms and angiosperms. Emphasis on nomenclature, structural characteristics, identification of species using a dichotomous key, and characteristics of plant families.
courses.name: Field Botany

courses.description: Common harmful and beneficial insects of this region and their control.
courses.name: Entomology

courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 1113, 1123. General principles of animal function.
courses.name: Animal Physiology

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior standing. An introduction to ethics and humanism in medicine as a means of understanding the basic values and tenets of the medical profession. The course is especially designed for students who plan to become physicians, physical therapists, physican assistants, nurse practitioners, and related health-care professionals.
courses.name: Humanism in Medicine

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 1113. Principles and laws governing inheritance in plants and animals, including man.
courses.name: General Genetics

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Locating and using resource materials, technical writing, and oral presentations in biological disciplines.
courses.name: Biological Comm Skills

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 1123 and BIOL 3120 or BIOL 3130 or WFS 3130. Biology of animal agents and vectors of diseases with emphasis placed on medical parasitology and organisms that parasitize fish and wildlife species.
courses.name: General Parasitology

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Introduction to basic principles of cellular and molecular immunology.
courses.name: Immunology

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 3140 and CHEM 1110 or CHEM 1210. A survey of hormones, their functions and mechanisms of action in vertebrate animals, including humans.
courses.name: Hormones & Chem Comm

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 1113 and BIOL 1123. Develo9pment of vertebrates from the origin of gametes through hatching or birth, including embryonic anatomy and physiology and events, mechanisms, facts, and theories influencing vertebrate development.
courses.name: Vertebrate Development

courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 3810 and BIOL 3130 or WFS 3130. Theories, evidences, principles, and examples of organic evolution. Emphasis on anatomical, chemical, ecological, geological, anthropological, and genetic factors.
courses.name: Evolutionary Biology

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 3200 or BIOL 3230. Survey of microbial diversity and an in-depth evaluation of evolutionary mechanisms that lead to microbial speciation.
courses.name: Microbial Evolution

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 3200 or BIOL 3230. Diversity, ecology, and taxonomy of protozoa, and the importance of protozoa as agents of human disease and as model organisms for studying eukaryotic cell biology.
courses.name: Protozoology

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 3200 or 3230. The function of microorganisms in the environment.
courses.name: Environmental Microbiology

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 3200 or BIOL 3230. Common Bacterial pathogens will be reviewed, including: 1. How they cause disease; 2. Virulence factors and how they are identified and studied; and 3. Prevention of disease transmission.
courses.name: Pathogenic Bacteriology

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 3810, CHEM 3005 or 3020. Molecular basis of inheritance with special emphasis on microorganisms.
courses.name: Molecular Genetics

courses.description: Prerequisite or corequisite: BIOL 4150. Techniques of bacterial genetics and recombinant DNA methodology.
courses.name: Genetic Engineering Lab

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 1123 and BIOL 3810. Introduction to empirical and theoretical conservation genetics.
courses.name: Population/Conserv Genetics

courses.description: Introduction to process-based models and all aspects of the model life cycle: equation generation, parameterization, evaluation, and utilization.
courses.name: Biological Systems Modeling

courses.description: Prerequisite: MATH 1530 or MATH 1830. Probability and frequency distribution; statistical populations and samples; and tests of hypotheses used in biological research. (Same as WFS 4220.)
courses.name: Biostatistics

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Introduction to basic principles underlying the behavior of animals. (Same as WFS 4230.)
courses.name: Animal Behavior

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 3240. Principles of evolutionary relationships among major plan groups, with an emphasis on the phylogeny of gymnosperms and flowering plant families.
courses.name: Systematic Botany

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 2310. Interrelationships between plants and people. Topics include a survey of the past, present, and future uses of plants and the role of conservation biology in the preservation of plant resources.
courses.name: Economic Botany

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 1123. Principles of the evolution of plants at the micro- and macroevolution levels, including a survey of relevant primary and secondary literature.
courses.name: Plant Speciation/Evolution

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 2310 and Junior standing. A comparative study of the structure of vascular plants in relation to function.
courses.name: Plant Anatomy

courses.description: Physiological activities of seed plants, including photosynthesis, respiration, mineral nutrition, flowering, seed formation, and dormancy.
courses.name: Plant Physiology

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 2310. Biotic and abiotic factors affecting the distribution and abundance of plant species and the role of plants in ecosystem structure and function.
courses.name: Plant Ecology

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 2310 and junior standing. Interactions of plants and animals in aquatic, terrestrial, and atmospheric environments at various ecological scales.
courses.name: Plant-Animal Interactions

courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 3130 or WFS 3130. Biology of invertebrates with emphasis on morphology, systematics and ecology.
courses.name: Invertebrate Zoology

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior standing. General survey of the class Aves with emphasis on morphology, identification and ecology of local birds. (Same as WFS 4630.)
courses.name: Ornithology

courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 3130 or WFS 3130. An introduction to the study of the marine environment and marine organisms. (Same as WFS 4650.)
courses.name: Marine Biology

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 3200 or 3230. A survey of microorganisms of medical importance with emphasis on the bacteria and viruses. Principles of infectious disease, including diagnostic methods and treatments. Laboratory exercises demonstrating methods of isolating and identifying pathogenic microorganisms.
courses.name: Medical Microbiology

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Introduction to freshwater algae.
courses.name: Phycology

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Identification, classification, anatomy, physiology, ecology, and adaptations of fishes; emphasis on North American freshwater species. (Same as WFS 4810.)
courses.name: Ichthyology

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Classification, structure and function, phylogeny, and geographical distribution of mammals; emphasis on Tennessee mammals. (Same as WFS 4820.)
courses.name: Mammalogy

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Classification, adaptations, habits, life histories, and geographical distribution of amphibians and reptiles; emphasis on North American species. (Same as WFS 4830.)
courses.name: Herpetology

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Physiochemical and biological dynamics of inland water. (Same as WFS 4840).
courses.name: Limnology

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 3200 or 3230. Microbial production of foods and chemicals; microorganisms in food spoilage.
courses.name: Applied Microbiology

courses.description: Mechanisms of disease transmission, persistence of pathogens, and infection control.
courses.name: Disease Prevention

courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 3200 or BIOL 3230. An in-depth look at how the microbes in and on the human body affect everyday life and health.
courses.name: Microbiomes

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior Standing. Introduction to the field of bioethics focusing on practical applications of ethical principles related to healthcare, medical science, and medical technology.
courses.name: Bioethics

courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 1113 and BIOL 1123 or BIOL 2010. A detailed study of the microscopic structure of human tissues along with their cellular components, the methods used to prepare tissue samples for microscopy, and various common staining techniques.
courses.name: Histology

courses.description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor required. Students work with a public agency or private company or organization that is compatible with their interest. (May be taken twice if the assignments are with different organizations or with different divisions with an organization.)
courses.name: Internship in Biology

courses.description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor and departmental chairperson. Focused study equivalent to one, two, three, or four credit hours on an advanced topic in the life sciences or wildlife/fisheries sciences under faculty supervision and approval of the department chairperson. Course may be repeated until a maximum of 12 hours of combined credit in BIOL (WFS) 299-Topics or BIOL (WFS) 499- (599-) Advanced Topics courses are earned.
courses.name: Advanced Topics

courses.description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor and departmental chairperson. Focused study equivalent to one, two, three, or four credit hours on an advanced topic in the life sciences or wildlife/fisheries sciences under faculty supervision and approval of the department chairperson. Course may be repeated until a maximum of 12 hours of combined credit in BIOL (WFS) 299-Topics or BIOL (WFS) 499- (599-) Advanced Topics courses are earned.
courses.name: Advanced Topics

courses.description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor and departmental chairperson. Focused study equivalent to one, two, three, or four credit hours on an advanced topic in the life sciences or wildlife/fisheries sciences under faculty supervision and approval of the department chairperson. Course may be repeated until a maximum of 12 hours of combined credit in BIOL (WFS) 299-Topics or BIOL (WFS) 499- (599-) Advanced Topics courses are earned.
courses.name: Advanced Topics

courses.description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor and departmental chairperson. Focused study equivalent to one, two, three, or four credit hours on an advanced topic in the life sciences or wildlife/fisheries sciences under faculty supervision and approval of the department chairperson. Course may be repeated until a maximum of 12 hours of combined credit in BIOL (WFS) 299-Topics or BIOL (WFS) 499- (599-) Advanced Topics courses are earned.
courses.name: Advanced Topics

courses.description: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing. Management functions and processes as applied to organizations with special emphasis on the behavioral aspects.
courses.name: Mgmt/Organizational Behavior

courses.description: Prerequisite: Consent of Management Internship Coordinator or Department Chairperson. A directed professional experience in the field of Management. Junior or Senior Standing Required.
courses.name: Internship in Management

courses.description: Prerequisite: BMGT 3510 and Junior standing. Explore organization and management issues in international business.
courses.name: International Management

courses.description: Prerequisite: BMGT 3510 and Junior standing. Personnel management policies, practices, and laws.
courses.name: Human Resource Management

courses.description: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing. Principles and practices in developing appropriate business messages that report primary and secondary research in a variety of styles.
courses.name: Business Communications I

courses.description: Prerequisites: BMGT3630. This course will focus on the recruitment, selection, and retention of human resources within organizations. Students will learn methods and processes by which organizations plan for their staffing needs, recruit applicants, select new employees, and socialize new employees. Students will also learn how the staffing function influences organizational performance and how the staffing function is influenced by the legal, social, organizational, and technological environments in which staffing decisions are made.
courses.name: Staffing

courses.description: Prerequisite: BMGT 3630. Theory and practice of determining wages, salaries, and employee benefits.
courses.name: Compensation Administration

courses.description: Prerequisites: BMGT3630. An overview of legal issues affecting the employment relationship in business, from a managerial perspective.
courses.name: Employment & Labor Law

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Development of interpersonal skills for managing conflict and negotiations in business.
courses.name: Conflict Mgmt & Negotiation

courses.description: Prerequisite: BMGT 3510 and Junior standing. An examination of behavioral concepts required for effective leadership within business organizations.
courses.name: Organizational Leadership

courses.description: Prerequisite: BMGT 3510 and Junior standing. Development of skills in employee development and training in a wide range of business contexts.
courses.name: Training and Development

courses.description: Prerequisite: BMGT 3720. Analyzing and presenting solutions for cases and problems involving business transactions.
courses.name: Business Communication II

courses.description: Consent of instructor. Current topics in management.
courses.name: Spec Topics in Management

courses.description: Prerequisites: BMGT 3510, FIN 3210 and MKT 3400, Prerequisite or corequisite: DS 3520. A capstone course stressing management problem analysis, problem solving, and decision-making. This course is designed to be taken during semester of graduation.
courses.name: Business Strategy

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior standing or above. From media tutorials (CD-ROM, videotape, etc.), personal tutorials, and workshops, the student learns at least three state-of-the-art applications of current computer technologies to community development projects. Student must sign a written intention to complete CAS 4910, 4920, and 4930. A-F grading.
courses.name: Intern-Tech/Comm Devlpmnt I

courses.description: Prerequisite: CAS 4910 or consent of the supervisor. The student collaborates with others in a workshop setting to practice at least three state-of-the-art applications of current computer technologies to community development projects. A-F grading.
courses.name: Intern-Tech/Comm Develop II

courses.description: Lab. 4-6. Credit 2-3.Prerequisite: CAS 4910 and CAS 4920 or consent of the supervisor. The student completes a community development project, or a substantial, definable part of a project, based on at least three state-of-the-art applications of current computer technologies. A-F grading.
courses.name: Intern-Tech/Comm Develop III

courses.description: Engages the student in meaningful academic and non-academic activities introducing students to the CEE department and the civil engineering profession. Emphasizes time management and study skills, department and university resources, faculty interaction, professional and student organizations, and the civil engineering profession.
courses.name: Connections-Civ & Env Engr

courses.description: Prerequisite: PHYS 2110 (PHYS 2110 may be taken concurrently); C or better in MATH 1920. Vector algebra, resultants, equilibrium, friction, centroids, moment of inertia, trusses, machines and frames, beam shear and moments.
courses.name: Statics

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior Standing. The course introduces students to the use of computer aided design and drafting software (CADD) and to instruct students in best practices for preparing Civil Engineering drawings.
courses.name: Civil Engineering Graphics

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3110. Characteristics and uses of aggregates, Portland cement, concrete and bituminous materials for highways and other major engineering works.t
courses.name: Civil Engineering Materials

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3030. Measurement of basic engineering properties of soils.
courses.name: Geotechnical Engr Lab

courses.description: Prerequisite: C or better in CEE 2110. Stress, strain, Hooke's law, extension, torsion, and bending; beam deflections, column buckling and combined stresses.
courses.name: Mechanics of Materials

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3110. A series of experiments which demonstrate the theory of mechanics of materials and the most important characteristics of engineering materials.
courses.name: Mech of Materials Lab

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3110. Analysis of statically determinate and indeterminate structures; influence lines; and moving loads. Classical and computer methods.
courses.name: Structural Mechanics

courses.description: Prerequisite: MATH 1710 or MATH 1730 or MAH 1910. Introduction to statics, mechanics of materials, and structural analysis; properties of commonly used structural materials, minimum design loads from ASCE 7. Not for Civil Engineering majors.
courses.name: Introduction to Structures

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 1110 and MATH 1920. Fundamentals of environmental engineering with applications in water quality, water and wastewater treatment, solid waste management, air pollution, and hazardous waste management.
courses.name: Environmental Engineering

courses.description: Prerequisite: ME 2330. Fundamental fluid mechanics with focus on hydraulic design of civil engineering systems. Topics include hydrostatics, kinematics, energy and momentum principles, flows through pipes and networks, introduction to open channel flow.
courses.name: Fluid Mechanics

courses.description: Prerequisite: ME 3720 or CEE 3415. Fundamental principles and design of water and wastewater supply, stormwater and sanitary sewer systems and their components, including pipes, pumps, storage facilities, detention basins, open-channels, and culverts.
courses.name: Hydraulics

courses.description: Prerequisite or corequisite: CEE 3413. Laboratory experiments to illustrate the application of engineering fundamentals to environmental systems.
courses.name: Environmental Engr Lab

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3710. The design and management of the construction phase of a project: scheduling, estimating, contracts, laws, financing, and safety.
courses.name: Intro-Construction Engr/Mgmt

courses.description: Prerequisite: MATH 1920. Introduction to the fundamental principles, instruments, and techniques associated with surveying for highway purposes.
courses.name: Surveying

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3600. Introduction to transportation engineering; planning, location, design, and operation of transportation facilities.
courses.name: Transportation Engineering

courses.description: Prerequisite: Math 1920. Concepts and techniques useful in the economic evaluation of engineering alternatives.
courses.name: Principles of Engineering Econ

courses.description: Prerequisite: MATH 1920. Engineering applications of probability, hypothesis testing, and confidence intervals.
courses.name: Principles of Engr Statistics

courses.description: Prerequisites: CEE 3320 or ME 3620 and MATH 2010 or MATH 4510. Matrix formulations using flexibility and stiffness methods for structural analysis of skeletal structures. Finite element formulations and applications.
courses.name: Matrix & Finite Element Method

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3110. Introduction to mechanics of fibrous, laminated composites. Micromechanics, mechanical properties, stiffness and strength, and classical laminate theory. Thermal and moisture effects. Effective engineering properties of laminates. Failure theories, design criteria, and computational implementation.
courses.name: Intro-Mechanics of Composites

courses.description: Prerequisites: CEE 3110, MATH 2120, or consent of instructor. Advanced topics, fracture mechanics, elastic support, non-circular shafts, curved beams, thick-walled cylinders, introduction to plates, and thin shells of revolution.
courses.name: Adv Mechanics of Materials

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3320. Design of members and structures in steel. Analysis and design of beams, tension members, compression members, members with combined stresses, and standard connections.
courses.name: Structural Steel Design

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3320. Design of members and structures in concrete. Design of beams, slabs, columns, and footings.
courses.name: Reinforced Concrete Design

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3320 or CEE 3340. Material properties of timber elements; design of timber beams, columns, and connection; light gauge steel properties and design; residential and commercial design considerations.
courses.name: Res & Light Comm Design

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 4310. Special topics in analysis and design of steel structures. Plastic design, composite design, plate girders, and special connections.
courses.name: Advanced Structural Design

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 4320. Special topics in the design of concrete structures. Combined footings, retaining walls, two-way slabs, and prestressed concrete.
courses.name: Adv Top/Struc Concrete Design

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3030 and CEE 4320. Masonry materials and construction. Design of masonry beams, walls, and columns. Seismic design of masonry structures.
courses.name: Masonry Design

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 4310. Design of structural steel and reinforced concrete bridges.
courses.name: Bridge Design

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 4380 (5380). Steel plate girder design; prestressed concrete girder design; bridge substructure design including multi-post piers, spread footings, point bearing piles, and friction piles.
courses.name: Bridge Design II

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3413 or consent of instructor. The collection and disposal of solid wastes. Treatment and disposal technologies of hazardous wastes.
courses.name: Solid & Hazard Waste Mgmt

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3420 or consent of instructor. Fundamental processes in the hydrologic cycle including precipitation, infiltration and runoff. Quantitative approaches for engineering hydrology to estimate flows for a variety of design problems.
courses.name: Engineering Hydrology

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 1120 and CEE 3413 or consent of instructor. Analytical methods for use in water quality management of streams, lakes, reservoirs and groundwater systems. Project design of water and wastewater treatment plants.
courses.name: Water/Wastewater Engr

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3420 or consent of instructor. Problems related to the planning and design of systems to manage water resources for flood-damage reduction, hydropower and river navigation.
courses.name: Water Resources Engineering

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 1120 and CEE 3413 or consent of instructor. Mathematical modeling of chemical and biological processes occurring in streams, lakes, and estuaries, emphasizing oxygen demand and nutrient processes.
courses.name: Water Quality Modeling

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3600 and CEE 3420. GIS & spatial data models; projections and coordinate systems; maps, data entry, editing & output; basic spatial analysis; GPS & GNSS; aerial & satellite images, terrain analysis; raster analysis; and spatial estimation.
courses.name: Geospatial Model/Analysis Engr

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHEM 1120, CEE 3413, CEE 3420, and consent of instructor. Real-world experience in the field of water resources and environmental engineering; apply theory and design knowledge gained in civil and environmental engineering courses to practice.
courses.name: Exp Lrn/Water Res/Env Engr

courses.description: Prerequisite: Senior standing in an engineering discipline. Management theory applied to engineering and technical organizations. Topics include management functions in an engineering context; engineering techniques and tolls for management; project management; management/leadership of technical people and teams; and contemporary engineering management topics, e.g., rapid technological change and globalization.
courses.name: Engineering Management

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3500. Estimating procedures, contract documents, quantity take-off, bidding strategy, and bid opening.
courses.name: Construction Est/Cost Control

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3500. Techniques used in controlling the progress of construction projects, including development of project schedule and monitoring progress using critical path methodology.
courses.name: Constr Proj Plng,Sch,Cntrl

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3500. Project security control, construction accident prevention, safety information sources, weather precautions, emergency planning, and OSHA procedures and regulations.
courses.name: Construction Safety

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3500. Materials, methods, and construction equipment.
courses.name: Constr Op, Materials, Methods

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3500. Contracts, torts, professional liability, labor laws, insurance, expert testimony, arbitration, sureties, and ethics.
courses.name: Legal Aspects in Construction

courses.description: Prerequisite: ENGR 1110 and CEE 4310 or CEE 4320 (CEE 4310 or CEE 4320 may be taken concurrently) Building configuration, layout, and modeling in steel, concrete, and masonry
courses.name: Building Information Modeling

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3500. Formwork, falsework, bracing, earth retention systems, cofferdams, scaffolding, and material handling equipment and staging.
courses.name: Temporary Structures

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3030. Design and testing of high-strength PCC, self-consolidating PCC, high volume fly ash PCC and pervious PCC. Controlled low-strength materials. Concrete formwork design. Masonry materials evaluation. Aggregate production and improvement.
courses.name: Civil Engineering Materials II

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3610. Structural design of flexible and rigid pavements. Pavement rehabilitation. Properties of subgrades, base courses, and paving materials.
courses.name: Pavement Design

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3610. Techniques of traffic engineering measurements, investigations and data analysis; design, application, and operation of traffic control systems and devices.
courses.name: Traffic Engineering

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3610. Theory and practice of highway geometric design, highway plans, construction practices, and computer applications to highway design.
courses.name: Highway Engineering

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3610. System planning and evaluation. Characteristics, impacts, and costs. User patterns. Alternative analysis.
courses.name: Transportation Planning

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3030 and GEOL 3210 or GEOL 1040. (CEE 3030 and GEOL 3210 may be taken concurrently). Soil physical properties, classification, permeability and seepage, consolidation, shear strength and introduction to foundations
courses.name: Geotechnical Engineering

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 4800. Soil mechanics (emphasis on stress and shear strength), bearing capacity, magnitude and time-rate of consolidation, geotechnical design of shallow and deep foundations.
courses.name: Foundation Engineering

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 4800. Soil mechanics (emphasis on stress and shear strength), lateral earth pressure, excavation systems and anchorage, mechanically stabilized earth walls, geotechnical design of retaining walls and excavation support.
courses.name: Retaining Walls & Excavations

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 4800 (CEE 4800 may be taken concurrently) and CEE 4310 or CEE 4320. Forensic case studies related to civil engineering
courses.name: Forensic Engineering

courses.description: Prerequisite: Senior standing. A discussion of the ethical, social, and economic considerations in engineering practice, and professional and technical societies.
courses.name: Professionalism & Ethics

courses.description: Prerequisites: MATH 2120 and PHYS 2110. Identification and description of noise sources and noise radiation, methods of noise measurements and criteria for noise levels, principles and techniques of noise control.
courses.name: Noise Control

courses.description: Prerequisite: CEE 3030, CEE 3413, CEE 3420, CEE 3610, CEE 3710, CEE 4310 or CEE 4320, CEE 4800, and CEE 4920 (CEE 3030, CEE 3420, CEE 3710, CEE 4310, CEE 4320, CEE 4800, and CEE 4920 may be taken concurrently). Review fundamentals in preparation for fundamentals-of-engineering (FE) test.
courses.name: Fundamentals of Civil Engr

courses.description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor. Comprehensive design project of civil engineering projects using a team approach.
courses.name: Senior Design Project

courses.description: Current topics in the student's area of interest. May not be repeated to improve a grade.
courses.name: Special Problems

courses.description: Prerequisite: Human Ecology and Child and Family Studies major and minor or consent of instructor. Introduction to college: the HEC/CFS majors and student opportunities. Review of the history, philosophy, trends, and professional publications and associations in HEC/CFS. Exploration of career opportunities.
courses.name: Intro to the Profession

courses.description: Development of individuals across the life span and factors that influence this development. Focus on biological, cognitive, and socio-emotional processes.
courses.name: Life Span Development

courses.description: Students participate in professional related activities via: diverse agency and educational settings through guided observations, interviews, and "hands-on" experiences; planned special activities; attendance at career-related events; and events of students' own choosing.
courses.name: Field Exp: Child & Fam Studies

courses.description: Corequisite: CFS 1310. Fundamental concepts and trends related to current challenges of families, marriage, parenthood, and work.
courses.name: Intro to the Family

courses.description: Corequisite: CFS 1300. Field experience in community agencies and organizations and family settings and their interrelationships.
courses.name: Field Exp: Family & Community

courses.description: The family as a social system. Family-community relationships including partnerships with families of children with special needs.
courses.name: The Family System

courses.description: Basic principles and theories of early childhood development, with emphasis on factors influencing typical development, the importance of developmentally appropriate practices, identification of at-risk populations, and understanding basic special needs principles and laws. Candidates will complete approximately 8-10 hours of observation.
courses.name: Devlpmnt: Conception-Age 9

courses.description: Corequisite CFS 2200. Learn and practice observational techniques, approaches, and instruments appropriate for young children in various settings.
courses.name: Field Exp:Observ-Yng Chldrn

courses.description: Knowledge of risk factors, developmental delay, and categories of disability. Understanding of special education and its emphasis on prevention, early intervention, and services in normal environments. Practicum embedded into course.
courses.name: Children With Special Needs

courses.description: Supervised participation in service delivery settings.
courses.name: Pract:Children W/ Spec Needs

courses.description: Basic principles of child development from ten to eighteen years.
courses.name: Dev:Middle Chld/Adolescence

courses.description: Child guidance techniques in family, educational, and community settings. Parenting styles and their influence on child development and the parent-child relationship. Techniques and strategies for supporting parents.
courses.name: Parenting & Child Guidance

courses.description: Prerequisite: Full admission to the Teacher Education Program. Study of the development of alliances among families, childrens' and families' advocates, and professionals. The development of collaboration and communication skills, including conferencing and interviewing skills. (Same as HEC 352: Parent Education, prior to Fall 1998.)
courses.name: Fam, Cmnty, Prof Partnerships

courses.description: Study of professional and multicultural issues. Examination of relevant professional topics, including legal and behavior/group management issues. Continued development of communication skills, including problem-solving, and conflict resolution.
courses.name: Sem: Professional Dev Issues

courses.description: Examination of important professional topics, including a personal and professional profile, a portfolio, a resume, professional behavior, and professional organizations. Analysis of personal and professional resources.
courses.name: Seminar: Education & Society

courses.description: Prerequisite: Senior standing. Preparation for internship. Involvement with community agencies and programs serving children and families.
courses.name: Community Field Experience

courses.description: Information is provided to potential chemical engineering majors in a variety of areas including: curriculum linkages, the profession, collaborative work environments, faculty interaction, mentoring opportunities, professional societies, and laboratory skills.
courses.name: Intro to Chemical Engr

courses.description: Professionalism and Ethics are central in the practice of Engineering. Fundamental program outcome addressed formally in this course and applied throughout the curriculum in various manners.
courses.name: Processes, Products & Ethics

courses.description: Prerequisites: ENGR 1120, CHEM 1120, and MATH 1910. Quantitative descriptions of chemical engineering systems. Conservation equations, rate processes, and mathematical analysis.
courses.name: Intro to Chem Engr Analysis

courses.description: Prerequisite: ENGR 1120 and MATH 1920. May be taken concurrently. Introduction to basic concepts of chemical engineering including unit analysis, balance concepts and various mathematical tools including use of software such as Excel, MatLab and Visual Basic.
courses.name: Intro to Chem/Bio An-Scl I

courses.description: Prerequisite: ENGR 1120, C or better in CHE 2015, MATH 1920 and CHEM 1120. Quantitative descriptions of chemical and biological engineering systems. Conservation of mass for single and multi-process units as well as for reactive and non-reactive systems. Lab introduces report writing and basic measurement techniques.
courses.name: Intro to Chem/Bio An-Scl II

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 2015. MInimum grade of C. CHE 2020, MATH 2110, and MATH 2120. Application of the 1st and 2nd Laws of Thermodynamics to the analysis of single and multi-phase processes for both closed and open systems.
courses.name: Thermodynamics-Chem Processes

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 3010, MATH 2110 and MATH 2120. Analysis and prediction of mixture properties at equilibrium in single and multiple phases. Lab is focused on solution thermodynamic topics and industrially-relevant separation processes.
courses.name: Sep & Sol Thermodynamics

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHE 2015, CHE 2020, MATH 2110, MATH 2120. Corerequisite: CHE 3051. Energy conservation principles. Experimental studies of diffusive heat transfer. Design and operation of systems for heat transfer with applications to heat exchange and diffusive motion.
courses.name: TS I: Cond., Rad., Diff

courses.description: Energy conservation principles. Experimental studies of diffusive heat transfer. Design and operation of systems for heat transfer with applications to heat exchange and diffusive motion.
courses.name: TS 1: Cond., Rad., Diff. Lab

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 2015, CHE 2020, MATH 2110 and MATH 2120. Energy and mass conservation principles. Experimental studies of heat and diffusive Mass transfer. Design and operation of systems for heat and mass transfer with applications to heat exchange and diffusive motion.
courses.name: Trans Sci I:Cond, Raditn, Diff

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 2010. Principles, design, and operation of equipment for the separation and purification of materials; emphasizes distillation, extraction, and leaching.
courses.name: Transfer Science II

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHE 3111, MATH 2110 and MATH 2120. Theory of mass and momentum conservation principles. Experimental studies of fluid mechanics. Design and operation of systems involving fluids with application to fluid flow and fluid property measurements. MATH 2110 may be taken concurrently with permission from the department.
courses.name: Transfer Sci II:Fluid Mech

courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 3200 or BIOL 3230. Biotechnology and bioprocess engineering represent important areas in which chemical engineers contribute to the design and development of solutions to complex problems in medicine, energy, food, and other areas. This course (with an integrated, hands-on lab component) involves a detailed exploration of these topics.
courses.name: Biotech & Bioprocess Engr

courses.description: Prerequisite/corequisite: CHE 3120. Experimental studies in fluid mechanics and heat transfer.
courses.name: Chem Engr Laboratory II

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHE 2015, MATH 2110, MATH 2120. Corequisites: CHE 3511. Analysis and prediction of mixture properties at equilibrium in single and multiple phases. Lab is focused on solution thermodynamic topics and industrially-relevant separation processes.
courses.name: Sep & Solutions Thermo 2

courses.description: Corequisite: CHE 3510. Analysis and prediction of mixture properties at equilibrium in single and multiple phases. Lab is focused on solution thermodynamic topics and industrially-relevant separation processes.
courses.name: Sep & Solution Thermo 2 Lab

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHE 3050, CHE 3051, MATH 2210, MATH 2120. Corequisite: CHE 3551. Theory of mass, momentum, and mechanical energy conservation principles. Characterization of flow regimens and key non-dimensional number of scaling. Experimental studies of fluid mechanics. Design and operation of systems involving fluids with application to fluid flow and fluid property measurements.
courses.name: TS II: Fluid Mechanics

courses.description: Theory of mass, momentum, and mechanical energy conservation principles. Characterization of flow regimens and key non-dimensional number of scaling. Experimental studies of fluid mechanics. Design and operation of systems involving fluids with application to fluid flow and fluid property measurements.
courses.name: TS II: Fluid Mechanics Lab

courses.description: Prerequisites: Minimum grade of C in ENGR 1120, MATH 1920 and CHE 2015. Decision-making techniques as applied to management of chemical processing plants.
courses.name: Chem Engr Operations

courses.description: Prerequisite: Minimum grade of C in CHE 2015. Decision-making techniques as applied to management of chemical processing plants.
courses.name: ChE Operations

courses.description: Prerequisite: MATH 1910. Critical Review of the historical development of energy resources. Key steps in the emergency of new energy sources and their displacement of previously dominant ones. Societal, economic, and environmental impacts of energy sources. Implications for energy today and into the future. Fundamental energy balances will be introduced.
courses.name: Innovation in Energy

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHE 3010, CHE 3050, CHE 3051, CHE 3510, CHE 3511, CHE 3550, CHE 3551. Corequisite: CHE 4051. Mathematical description of diffusion and diffusive-convective mass transfer. Mass transfer with reaction. Dimensional Analysis. Mass transfer in one and two-dimensions in Cartesian, cylindrical, and spherical coordinates. Integrated labs demonstrating the concept of diffusion, computational experiments, and demonstrating the effect of geometry, flow, etc., on mass transfer.
courses.name: TS III: Mass Transfer

courses.description: Mathematical description of diffusion and diffusive-convective mass transfer. Mass transfer with reaction. Dimensional Analysis. Mass transfer in one and two-dimensions in Cartesian, cylindrical, and spherical coordinates. Integrated labs demonstrating the concept of diffusion, computational experiments, and demonstrating the effect of geometry, flow, etc., on mass transfer.
courses.name: TS III: Mass Transfer Lab

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHE 3010, CHE 3050, CHE 3051, CHE 3510, CHE 3511, CHE 3550, CHE 3551. Corequisite: CHE 4061. Chemical reaction kinetics and chemical reactor design. There is an emphasis on homogeneous reactions and ideal and non-ideal reactors. Introduction to laboratory experiments to illustrate typical situations found in chemical reacting systems: kinetics parameter determination, residence time visualization, and introduction to different types of reactors, (i.e., batch, tubular and gradient-less).
courses.name: Chemical Reaction Engineering

courses.description: Chemical reaction kinetics and chemical reactor design. There is an emphasis on homogeneous reactions and ideal and non-ideal reactors. Introduction to laboratory experiments to illustrate typical situations found in chemical reacting systems: kinetics parameter determination, resident time visualization, and introduction to different types of reactors, (i.e., batch, tubular and gradient-less).
courses.name: Chemical Reaction Engr Lab

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 2010. Principles, design, and operation of equipment for the separation and purification of materials.
courses.name: Transfer Science III

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 3010, CHE 3021, CHE 3111 and CHE 3121. Mathematical description of diffusion and diffusive-convective mass transfer. Mass transfer with reaction. Dimensional Analysis. Mass transfer in one and two-dimensions in Cartesian, cylindrical, and spherical coordinates. Integrated labs demonstrating the concept of diffusion, computational experiments, and demonstrating the effect of geometry, flow, etc., on mass transfer.
courses.name: Trans Sci III:D&D Mass Trans

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 3010, CHE 3021, CHE 3111 and CHE 3121. Chemical reaction kinetics and chemical reactor design. There is an emphasis on homogeneous reactions and ideal and non-ideal reactors. Introduction to laboratory experiments to illustrate typical situations found in chemical reacting systems: kinetics parameter determination, residence time visualization, and introduction to different types of reactors, (i.e., batch, tubular and gradientless).
courses.name: Chem Reaction Engr

courses.description: Prerequisite/corequisite: CHE 3120. Laboratory experiences in typical chemical engineering systems. Experiments are designed to integrate the subject matter from several subject areas.
courses.name: Chem Engineering Lab III

courses.description: Prerequisites: Either CHE 3021 or CHE 3510, either CHE 3121 or CHE 3550, either CHE 4131 or CHE 4050, either CHE 4210 or CHE 4060, CHE 4410, CHEM 3010 (may take CHEM 3010 concurrently). Project serves as a culminating experience for the student. Project content varies depending on the interests of the student, project team, and project sponsors. Projects serve to integrate junior- and senior-level coursework, promote an understanding of team dynamics and the development of project management skills. *Senior Standing in Chemical Engineering: Transfer Science I, II, III; Thermodynamics, Process Design I; Organic Chemistry I; Chemical Reaction Engineering. Senior Standing by cumulative credit hours is not adequate.
courses.name: Chem Engr Capstone Project

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior or Senior standing in chemical engineering or other engineering discipline, or consent of the instructor. This course focuses on team-based identification of unmet medical needs and development of robust solutions. Select disease conditions will be discussed and technologies used to address those conditions will be examined. Students will participate in simulation lab and clinical immersion for experiential learning in hospitals, urgent care facilities, assisted living facilities, senior citizen centers, and/or other healthcare settings.
courses.name: Clinical Immersion

courses.description: Prerequisites: Either CHE 3021 or CHE 3510, either CHE 3121 or CHE 3550, either CHE 4131 or CHE 4050, either CHE 4210 or CHE 4060, CHE 4410, CHEM 3010 (may take CHEM 3010 concurrently). Project serves as a culminating experience for the student. Project content varies depending on the interests of the student, project team, and project sponsors. Projects serve to integrate junior- and senior-level coursework, promote an understanding of team dynamics and the development of project management skills. *Senior Standing in Chemical Engineering; Transfer Science I, II, III; Thermodynamics, Process Design I; Organic Chemistry I; Chemical Reaction Engineering..
courses.name: ChE Capstone Laboratory

courses.description: CHE 4131. Problems of air pollution and their solutions. Analysis and design of devices for the control of air pollutants from chemical processes.
courses.name: Intro to Air Pollution

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 3010. Polymerization kinetics for key commercial polymers, structure/property relationships and characterization of key polymers, processing fundamentals, fundamentals of formulation of polymer composites and blends (nanocomposites, biopolymers).
courses.name: Polymer Engineering

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 3010 or ME 3210. Emphasis will be on electrochemical techniques, fundamental principles and technologies related to proton exchange membrane fuel cells. The course will delineate theoretical energy vs. specific losses: including ohmic, mass transport, and catalytic losses. Advanced materials for specific proton exchange membrane fuel cells will be discussed and diagnostic testing methodologies will be demonstrated (polarization curves, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, and cyclic voltammetry).
courses.name: Fuel Cells

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 3121. This course introduces the science of Rheology and its applications in chemical and petrochemical, food, pharmaceutical, and polymer industries. The concepts of Non-Newtonian behavior and continuous deformation are followed by discussions of viscosity and factors affecting viscosity of fluids, viscosity measurements and rheometers, shear diagrams, rehological equations of state, Bingham materials, shear thinning and shear thickening fluids, thicksotropy & time dependency, dilatent materials, viscoelastic materials, as well as various governing rheological and fluid flow equations and their applications. Industrial Applications are discussed via case studies of topics selected by students and presented to class.
courses.name: Introduction to Rheology

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHE 3021, and CHE 3121. Design and synthesis of chemical systems using basic engineering principles with integration of reliability, safety and environmental aspects. The economics involved in the design of chemical plants such as capital cost, profitability, operating costs, and alternative evaluation.
courses.name: Process Design I

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 4410. Continuation of Design I but with emphasis on complex chemical systems and innovation in design . Introduction to process modeling, the use of computer-aided process design, and analysis.
courses.name: Process Design II

courses.description: Prerequisites: Biochemistry and Cell & Molecular Biology are encouraged but not required. Students will apply principles of molecular biology and protein engineering to improve the properties of a selected protein. Computational tools and experimental methods will be applied to mutate and enhance the characteristics of proteins, which will hopefully lead to publishable results. Students will have to think about the subject creatively and use more than just knowledge from a textbook to solve the challenges encountered in the course.
courses.name: Protein Engineering

courses.description: Prerequisite: Senior standing in engineering, mathematics, chemistry (calculus-based), or physics. Selected materials synthesis for metals, ceramics, and their composites; application of fracture mechanics and failure models; mechanical, chemical, and morphological characterization theory and practice; and materials design.
courses.name: Intdisc Stu/Cermc Mtrl Process

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 3020, CHE 3120 or equivalents and MATH 2120. Applied numerical methods, and the solution of differential equations in chemical engineering.
courses.name: Appl Math in Chem Engr

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 4131 and CHE 4210. Analysis of the dynamic behavior of chemical processes. Basic control principles and methods of measuring and controlling process variables.
courses.name: Process Dynamics and Control

courses.description: Prerequisites: MATH 1920 and CHEM 3010. This course focuses on including environmental objectives during the design of chemical processes. Environmental objectives include sustainable energy use, global warming, ozone, air quality, water quality, and zero discharge. Risk concepts, environmental legislation and evaluation of fate based on chemical structure are reviewed. Pollution prevention and analysis are covered with attention to unit operations of the chemical reactor and catalysis. Critical review of literature sources is emphasized.
courses.name: Green Engineering

courses.description: Prerequisite: MATH 2120. Minimum Grade of C. Special topics in Chemical Engineering with engineering content in nuclear power, solar power, alternative energy storage or production, carbon sequestration, economics of energy infrastructure.
courses.name: Energy/Environment Sp Topics

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 4410. This course provides an introductory overview of several manufacturing strategies. It starts with a review of the characteristics of Mass Manufacturing and Lean Manufacturing and introduces the concept of Agile Manufacturing. It is proposed that the businesses practicing ‘mass manufacturing’ tend to invest funds in equipment and facilities as opposed to technology, people and information systems. Businesses practicing ‘lean manufacturing’ become cost efficient producers of goods and services by reducing waste and investing in technology. However, businesses practicing ‘agile manufacturing’ invest in people and information systems, respond quickly to market changes and anticipate the future demands of customers. The course covers the differences among the various modes of manufacturing as well as the advantages and disadvantages that each offers and introduces students to topics, such as: concept-to-cash time, virtual organizations, rapid Response to unanticipated changes, customer-focus approach, supply chain management, and innovation and implementation of advanced technologies. Additionally, brief discussions of ‘event-oriented thinking’ versus ‘systems-thinking’ will be included. The lectures will be followed by several case studies. Students will be asked to research individual cases involving real companies, based on publicly available literature, evaluate them, based on agile manufacturing criteria that they have learned in class, and regularly present their findings and conclusions in form of reports and presentations to the class as a whole.
courses.name: Agile Manufacturing

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 4210 or consent of instructor. Applications of chemical engineering principles to the study of biochemical systems.
courses.name: Biochemical Engineering

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHE 3111, CHE 3121, CHE 4131 and CHE 4210 or consent of instructor. Applications of chemical engineering principles to the study of biochemical and biological systems. Lab is centered around various techniques used in the biochemical and biological field.
courses.name: Transport in Biochem/Biol Proc

courses.description: Prerequisite: Students approved for BS-MS Fast Track. Presentation and discussion of topics relevant to the ethics and professional behavior in the chemical engineering profession, including professional licensure. Research methodology and graduate studies preparation is also discussed.
courses.name: Prof & Ethic-ChE-BS/MS Fst Trk

courses.description: Special Topics in Chemical Engineering taught on an as needed basis.
courses.name: Special Topics in Chem Engr

courses.description: Special Topics in Chemical Engineering taught on an as needed basis.
courses.name: Special Topics in Chem Engr

courses.description: Special Topics in Chemical Engineering taught on an as needed basis.
courses.name: Special Topics in Chem Engr

courses.description: Prerequisite: Consent of Instructor. Restrictions: Junior or Senior standing in Chemical Engineering. Research and development problems, laboratory investigations, planning experimental programs, and correlating and reporting results through written works and presentations. Because of the impossibility of duplicating the conditions on a special problem, this course may not be repeated for the improvement of a grade.
courses.name: Intro to Research

courses.description: An introductory course for students without sufficient high school background in chemistry. Topics include metric system, atomic structure, bonding, stoichiometry, solutions, and some descriptive chemistry. Not degree credit as Chemistry course. May be used for elective credit in some programs. Students may not register for this course if they have credit for any other college chemistry course. May not be taken concurrently with any chemistry course, excluding CHEM 1500.
courses.name: Chemistry Problem Solving

courses.description:
Prerequisites: CHEM 1010 is prerequisite to 1020. Overview of chemical principles and applications. Laboratories emphasize general principles of chemistry.
Meets Tennessee Technological University general education requirement (Natural Sciences).  Chemistry majors may not earn credit in both CHEM 1010 and 1110 or both 1020 and 1120.  Credit will not be given for both CHEM 1210, 1310 and any of the above courses.
courses.name: Introductory Chemistry I

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 1010. Overview of chemical principles and applications. Laboratories emphasize general principles of Chemistry.Chemistry majors may not earn credit in both CHEM 1010 and 1110 or both 1020 and 1120. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 1210, 1310 and any of the above courses.Meets Tennessee Technological University general education requirement (Natural Sciences).
courses.name: Introductory Chemistry II

courses.description: Corequisite: CHEM 1000. Selected experiments to complement lecture material in CHEM 1000.
courses.name: Foundations of Chem Lab

courses.description: Prerequisites: ACT Math score of 19 or higher; or SAT Math score of 530 or higher; or B or higher in CHEM 1000; or C or higher in MATH 1710; or Accuplacer QAS score of 250-300; or AAF 231 or greater. General chemistry course for students pursuing a degree in a STEM-related field. Topics include atomic and molecular level structure and properties, stoichiometry, aqueous reactions, thermochemistry, and properties of gases. Associated laboratory supports lecture content and incorporates elements of atomic emission spectroscopy and stoichiometric calculations.Meets Tennessee Technological University general education requirement (Natural Sciences).
courses.name: General Chemistry I

courses.description: Corequisite: CHEM 1110. An ACT score of 30 or higher is also recommended. Selected topics to add depth to the understanding of the material in CHEM 1110. Honors students can receive honors credit for CHEM 1110 by satisfactorily completing both CHEM 1110 and CHEM 1111.
courses.name: Gen Chem I Honors Ret

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 1110 with a grade of C or better. General chemistry course for students pursuing a degree in a STEM-related field. Topics include properties of liquids and solids, solutions, kinetics, thermodynamics, equilibrium, and electrochemistry. Associated laboratory supports lecture content and incorporates elements of molecular absorption spectroscopy ad equilibrium calculations.Meets Tennessee Technological University general education requirement (Natural Sciences). Chemistry majors may not earn credit in both CHEM 1010 and 1110 or both 1020 and 1120. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 1210, 1310 and any of the above courses.
courses.name: General Chemistry II

courses.description: Corequisite: CHEM 1120. A grade of A or B in CHEM 1110 is also recommended. Selected topics to add depth to the understanding of the material in CHEM 1120. Honors students can receive honors credit for CHEM 1120 by satisfactorily completing both CHEM 1120 and CHEM 1121.
courses.name: Gen Chem II-Hon Recitation

courses.description:
Introduction to chemical principles and their applications to health and disease, which will include chemical structures, moles, organic chemistry and biochemistry.  A knowledge of general mathematics is needed for the use of conversion factors, making of solutions, and calculation of dosages and dilutions.  This course will not count as part of a chemistry sequence.
Chemistry majors may not earn credit in both CHEM 1010 and 1110 or both 1020 and 1120.  Credit will not be given for both CHEM 1210, 1310 and any of the above courses.
courses.name: Chemistry for Life Sciences

courses.description: Basic principles of chemistry including atomic structure, chemical bonding, basic stoichiometry, organic and inorganic compounds, and kinetic theory. Will not count as part of a chemistry sequence.Chemistry majors may not earn credit in both CHEM 1010 and 1110 or both 1020 and 1120. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 1210, 1310 and any of the above courses.
courses.name: Concepts of Chemistry

courses.description: This course engages the student in meaningful classroom and out-of-the-classroom activities. This is intended for chemistry majors and emphasizes information, activities, and requirements important to becoming an active and competent chemist.
courses.name: 1st-Yr Interactions/Advisement

courses.description: Prerequisites: Consent of chair and instructor. Timely topics in chemistry. Course may be taken for credit more than once.
courses.name: Sp Topics/Gen Chem

courses.description: Prerequisites: Consent of chair and instructor. Timely topics in chemistry. Course may be taken for credit more than once.
courses.name: Sp Topics/Gen Chem

courses.description: Prerequisites: Consent of chair and instructor. Timely topics in chemistry. Course may be taken for credit more than once.
courses.name: Sp Topics/Gen Chem

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 1120. Introduction to the basic principles of inorganic chemistry including bonding, nomenclature, coordination chemistry, molecular orbital theory, and basic transition metal organometallic chemistry.
courses.name: Intro to Inorganic Chemistry

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 3010. Principles of pharmacology including chemical structures, actions and reactions of drugs. Does not count as technical elective in chemistry.
courses.name: Clinical Pharmacology

courses.description: Development of the scientific theories and concepts from antiquity through the 18th century. Does not count as technical elective in chemistry.
courses.name: Hist of Scientific Thought

courses.description: Development of natural sciences in the 19th and 20th centuries. Does not count as technical elective in chemistry.
courses.name: Hist of Scientific Thought

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHEM 1110, with a grade of C or better, or MATH ACT score of 27 or higher. CHEM 2910 is designed to introduce undergraduate students to the methods used in conducting research. This course is designed to teach students key skills utilized in a research setting, methods of data analysis, as well as how to disseminate information obtained through research. Upon completion of this course, students will be prepared to work effectively in a chemistry department research lab.
courses.name: Undergraduate Research Methods

courses.description: Prerequisities: Successful completion of CHEM 2910 with a B or better. CHEM 2920 is designed to apply and utilize the skills obtained in Undergraduate Research Methods (CHEM 2910) in a laboratory setting. Students will work with a faculty mentor on the research project that was assigned to them in CHEM 2910. Work on this project will allow students to build practical research skills that can be transferred to other research projects. Students will also disseminate the findings of their project at Research and Creative Activities Day.
courses.name: UG Research Methods II

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 1020 or 1120. Aliphatic and aromatic organic chemistry for students in agriculture, human ecology, and pre-medical technology. Not for chemistry majors.
courses.name: Elementary Organic Chemistry

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 1120 with a grade of C or better. Study of carbon-containing compounds using the functional group approach and an emphasis in simple mechanisms of aliphatic and aromatic compounds.
courses.name: Organic Chemistry I

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM3010 with a grade of C or better. Study of carbon-containing compounds using the functional group approach and an emphasis in simple mechanisms of aliphatic and aromatic compounds.
courses.name: Organic Chemistry II

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 1120. Introduction to chemical analysis including titrimetric and gravimetric methods involving acid-base, oxidation-reduction, and complexometric techniques. Application of mass action, equilibria, and indicators to chemical analysis. Introduction to instrumental analysis including electrochemical and spectroscopic methods.
courses.name: Quantitative Analysis

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 3410. The application of wet chemical and instrumental methods of analysis to real problems in chemistry, biochemistry, and the environment.
courses.name: Analytical Applications

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 1120 and MATH 1830 or 1910. Survey of physical chemistry designed for those desiring the B.S. degree with a major in chemistry, education, pre-professional studies, biology or students in general.
courses.name: Elements/Physical Chemistry

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHEM 1120, MATH 1920, PHYS 2020 or PHYS 2110 (may be taken concurrently). Introduction to modern, molecular approach to physical chemistry. A moderately rigorous introduction to quantum chemistry covering symmetry, bonding, molecular spectroscopy and statistical mechanics to set a stage for the molecular treatment of thermodynamics and kinetics in CHEM 3520. Lectures are reinforced by a systematic set of modern spectroscopy laboratory experiments.
courses.name: Physical Chemistry I

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 3510. Kinetic theory of gases and Boltzmann distribution, Classical thermodynamics, adiabatic changes and Maxwell equations, heat capacity and equipartition theorem, thermodynamic and statistical entropy, chemical equilibrium, Electrochemistry, Phase transitions and thermodynamic aspects of phases, introduction to chemical kinetics and reaction dynamics. Lectures are reinforced by a systematic set of classical experiments in thermodynamics and kinetics.
courses.name: Physical Chemistry II

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHEM 1110, 1120, six additional hours of Chemistry and consent of a faculty research mentor and the departmental chairperson. Independent study of special topics in chemical education under the direction of a faculty mentor. Must be taken twice, preferably in consecutive semesters. Restricted to secondary education chemistry majors.
courses.name: Spl Prob in Chem Education

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHEM 2010 and CHEM 3500 or 3510. Correlation of physical and chemical properties of inorganic compounds and atomic structure.
courses.name: Inorganic Chemistry

courses.description: Corequisite: CHEM 4110 (5110). Synthesis, isolation, and characterization of inorganic compounds, using conventional as well as microscale and inert gas techniques.
courses.name: Inorganic Chemistry Lab

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHEM 3020 and 3500 or 3510. Preparation, structure, physical and chemical properties of organic polymers. Experimental determination of average molar mass and its correlation to macrioscopic properties. Thermal and viscoelastic behavior.
courses.name: Chemistry of Polymers

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 3500 or 3510 (may be taken concurrently). Introduction to theory of nuclear stability and decay processes. The laboratory emphasizes the detection, safe handling, and use of radioisotopes in chemical investigations.
courses.name: Nuclear Chem & Radiochemistry

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHEM 3020 and CHEM 3500 or 3510. The isolation and identification of organic compounds by both chemical and physical means with emphasis on spectroscopic methods.
courses.name: Spectro Ident-Organ Comp

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 1120, 3020 and 3410. This course will examine the application of chemical concepts and methods to the analysis of crime scene evidence.
courses.name: Forensic Chemistry

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 3005. Introduction to the chemistry of biological molecules and the metabolic pathways as related to nutrition and physiological function. (Not for chemistry majors.)
courses.name: Nutritional Biochemistry

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHEM 3410, 3510. Theory and practice of atomic spectroscopy, chromatography, and electroanalysis; discussion of selected instrumental techniques for analysis of surfaces, molecules, and particles.
courses.name: Instrumental Analysis

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 3010 and 3020, or consent of instructor. Chemistry of amino acids, proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, membranes and nucleic acids. Includes study of pH, enzyme kinetics, three-dimensional structure, and biochemical separation methods and analysis.
courses.name: General Biochemistry I

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 4610 (5610). Intermediary metabolism and its regulation, bioenergetics and photosynthesis, biosynthesis of proteins and nucleic acids.
courses.name: General Biochemistry II

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 4610 (5610) or CHEM 4300. Laboratory techniques associated with contemporary general biochemistry to include buffer preparation, pKa determination, amino acid analysis, protein expression, separation and purification techniques, protein determination, enzymology, equilibrium and binding constant determinations, and carbohydrate analysis. The CHEM 5650 student will engage in additional procedures in some of the experiments.
courses.name: General Biochemistry Lab

courses.description: Prerequisites: CHEM 3005 or 3010, and CHEM 3410 or 3500 or 3510 (courses from the latter group may be taken concurrently). Basic concepts of environmental chemistry.
courses.name: Environmental Chemistry

courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 4710 (5710). Advanced topics within environmental chemistry including emphasis on organic, inorganic, and analytical environmental chemistry. Case studies and contemporary literature in the field will be discussed.
courses.name: Adv Environmental Chemistry

courses.description: Prerequisite: One year of chemistry. Topics to be taught include the chemical literature, employment and interviewing, computer literacy, and the organization and oral presentation of current topics in chemistry.
courses.name: Chemistry Seminar

courses.description: Prerequisites: 18 hours of chemistry, Junior-Senior standing and consent of the chair. Supervised chemical work experience in a private or public agency that is related to the student’s career goals. A minimum equivalent to ten weeks of half-time employment is required. Cannot be used to replace core or required elective CHEM courses within the major requirements.
courses.name: Internship in Chemistry

courses.description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor. Timely topics in chemistry. Course may be taken for credit more than once.
courses.name: Special Topics

courses.description: Lec. 0. Credit 1.Dissemination of independent research conducted with a Chemistry faculty advisor through participation in meetings (national meetings, state meetings and/or TTU Student Research Day), departmental seminar, and mini-thesis.
courses.name: Distinction in Chem Research

courses.description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor and departmental chairperson. Study in chemical research; to provide experience in the methodology of experimental investigation. (Maximum credit toward degree is four hours.) May not be repeated to improve grade.
courses.name: Undergraduate Research

courses.description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor and departmental chairperson. Study in chemical research; to provide experience in the methodology of experimental investigation. (Maximum credit toward degree is four hours.) May not be repeated to improve grade.
courses.name: Undergraduate Research

courses.description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor and departmental chairperson. Study in chemical research; to provide experience in the methodology of experimental investigation. (Maximum credit toward degree is four hours.) May not be repeated to improve grade.
courses.name: Undergraduate Research

courses.description: Credit 0.Faculty mentor supervised creative inquiry experience during the summer terms. A maximum equivalent of ten weeks of part-time employment is possible. Zero-credit class.
courses.name: Creative Inquiry Summer Exp

courses.description: Orients students to theoretical content on the person-in-environment focus in Social Work. An ecological model with a lifespan approach is utilized to explore the periods from conception through late adulthood to understand individuals as they develop throughout the life cycle.
courses.name: Behavior Social Environment I

courses.description: This second course in the HBSE sequence expands the students’ knowledge of theoretical content, building on the ecological model and lifespan approach to understand individuals as they develop and have membership in families, groups, communities, and organizations.
courses.name: Behavior Social Environment II

courses.description: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing. Crime, the criminal and society's responses to the behavior.
courses.name: Criminology

courses.description: Introduction to contemporary police organization and operations.
courses.name: Police and Society

courses.description: Substantive criminal law and the rights of defendants to criminal charges.
courses.name: Criminal Law & Procedure

courses.description: Prerequisite: CJ 2850. Rules and exceptions governing the admission and exclusion of evidence including such issues as relevancy, presumptions, and burden of proof.
courses.name: Rules of Evidence

courses.description: Prerequisite: POLS 1030 American Government (Cyber edition) or consent of instructor.  Exploration of domestic and international cyber terror threats and concomitant responses by government and industry.
courses.name: Cyber Terrorism

courses.description: Prerequisite: SOC 1010 or consent of Instructor. In-depth analysis of interactions between technology and the law.
courses.name: Cyberlaw

courses.description: State wildlife laws and practices used in their enforcement. Enrollment primarily restricted to WFS majors.
courses.name: Wildlife Law Enforcement

courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior standing and SOC 1010 or CJ (SOC) 2660. Administration of the criminal process with particular attention to recent U.S. Supreme Court decisions regarding the Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Amendments.
courses.name: Advanced Criminal Procedure

courses.description: Prerequisite: SOC 1010 or CJ 2660. Students must be majoring in SOC, SOC/CJ or SOC/SW. Non-majors may be admitted by consent of instructor. This course provides an in-depth analysis of the victims of criminal activity including: the various challenges victims face as they seek justice through the criminal justice system; the risk factors and probability of experiencing crime; and, specific theoretical perspectives that center on the victims of crime. Topics such as restorative justice and victim blaming are also explored.
